data.name: Title_OriginalVisibleClipFormat
data.value: Original Visible Clip Bounds: {{X = {0}, Y = {1}, Size = {2}x{3}}}

data.name: ToolTipText_CompoundAnimation
data.value: Toggles whether the animation is handled as a single image. • When checked, animation will play and saving as GIF saves the whole animation. • When not checked, frame navigation will be enabled and saving saves only the selected frame.

data.name: ToolTipText_CompoundMultiSize
data.value: Toggles whether the icon is handled as a multi-resolution image. • When checked, always the best fitting image is displayed and saving as Icon saves every image. • When not checked, icon images can be explored by navigation and saving saves the selected image only.

data.name: ToolTipText_CompoundMultiPage
data.value: Toggles whether the pages are handled as a compound image. • When checked, saving as TIFF saves every page. • When not checked, saving saves always the selected page only.

data.name: ConfirmMessage_OverwriteInstallation
data.value: Are you sure you want to overwrite this installation?

data.name: ConfirmMessage_InstallClassicVisualizers
data.value:
For Visual Studio 2022 version 17.9 Preview 1 or higher it is not required to install the classic visualizers at this path if you use the KGy SOFT Image DebuggerVisualizers x64 package from Visual Studio Marketplace. The package offers modern non-dialog visualizers that can remain open while stepping through the code.
Do you really want to install the classic visualizers at this path?
Yes: Install the classic visualizers. No: Close the dialog and navigate to the Visual Studio Marketplace. Cancel: Do nothing.

data.name: ConfirmMessage_NetCoreDebuggerVisualizers
data.value:
This is the .NET Core build of KGy SOFT Imaging Tools. To install debugger visualizers you need to use a .NET Framework build.
Do you want to visit the Visual Studio Marketplace where you can download the installer of the debugger visualizers?

data.name: ConfirmMessage_Net472DebuggerVisualizers
data.value:
This is the .NET Framework 4.7.2 build of KGy SOFT Imaging Tools. To install the classic debugger visualizers you need to use a build targeting .NET Framework 4.6.2 or lower.
Do you want to visit the GitHub page where you can download various builds for different target platforms?

data.name: ConfirmMessage_DiscardChanges
data.value: There are unsaved modifications. Are sure to discard the changes?

data.name: ConfirmMessage_ResourceVersionMismatch
data.value: One or more selected items are for a different Imaging Tools version. Are you sure you want to continue?

data.name: ConfirmMessage_ResourceUnknownLibraries
data.value: One or more selected items contain resources for unknown libraries. This may occur if a selected item is for a newer Imaging Tools version. Are you sure you want to continue? If so, the resources for the unknown libraries will be skipped.

data.name: InfoMessage_QuantizerMayHaveNoEffect
data.value: The selected quantizer uses more colors than the original image. It is possible that is has no effect.

data.name: InfoMessage_ArgbQuantizerHasNoEffect
data.value: The selected quantizer can only remove partial transparency, but it has practically no effect as source has no alpha.

data.name: InfoMessage_SamePixelFormat
data.value: The selected pixel format is the same as the original one.

data.name: InfoMessage_AlphaTurnsBlack
data.value: Without selecting a quantizer possible alpha pixels of the source image are blended with black. By selecting a quantizer you can specify a different back color.

data.name: InfoMessage_ResourceVersionMismatch
data.value: This item is for a different Imaging Tools version.

data.name: InfoMessage_QuantizerAutoSelectedFormat
data.value: A quantizer has been auto selected for pixel format '{0}' using default settings. Use a specific instance to adjust parameters.

data.name: InfoMessage_PaletteAutoSelectedFormat
data.value: A system default palette of {0} colors has been auto selected for pixel format '{1}'. Select a quantizer to use specific colors and settings.

data.name: InfoMessage_DithererIgnoredFormat
data.value: The ditherer is ignored for pixel format '{0}' if there is no quantizer specified.

data.name: InfoMessage_PixelFormatUnnecessarilyWideFormat
data.value: {0} is the lowest compatible pixel format, which still supports the selected quantizer.

data.name: InfoMessage_QuantizerCanBeDitheredFormat
data.value: The selected quantizer represents a narrower set of colors than the original '{0}'. Dithering may help to preserve more details.

data.name: InfoMessage_PixelFormatCanBeDitheredFormat
data.value: The selected pixel format represents a narrower set of colors than the original '{0}'. Dithering may help to preserve more details.

data.name: InfoMessage_About
InfoMessage_EasterEgg
data.value:
Just a regular ToolStrip menu, eh?
Now imagine every combination of target platforms (from .NET Framework 3.5 to .NET 5), operating systems (from Windows XP to Linux/Mono), different DPI settings, enabled/disabled visual styles and high contrast mode, right-to-left layout...
Harmonizing visual elements for all possible environments is never a trivial task, but OMG, the ToolStrip wasn't a cakewalk. Would you believe that each and every combination had at least one rendering issue? My custom-zoomable ImageViewer control with the asynchronously generated resized interpolated images on multiple cores was an easy-peasy compared to that...

data.name: InfoMessage_PackageInstalledFormat
data.value: KGy SOFT Imaging Tools v{0} and the debugger visualizers have been installed.

data.name: InfoMessage_PackageUpgradedFormat
data.value: KGy SOFT Imaging Tools v{0} and the debugger visualizers have been upgraded to version v{1}.

data.value: Applying changes was attempted in a state when messaging was not available. Try again later.

data.value: Could not load the debugger visualizer due to an error: {0}

data.name: ErrorMessage_DebuggerVisualizerCannotApplyFormat
data.value: Could not apply the changes due to an error: {0}

data.name: WarningMessage_DebuggerVisualizerCannotUpdateFormat
data.value: Failed to update the debugger visualizer: {0}

data.name: gbPixelFormat.ToolTipText
data.value: Check to change the pixel format. When changing to a lower bit-per-pixel format, it is recommended to enable dithering.

data.name: gbQuantizer.ToolTipText
data.value: Check to use a quantizer. Quantizing allows reducing the number of colors even without changing the pixel format. For lower bit-per-pixel quantizers it is recommended to enable dithering.

data.name: cmbQuantizer.ToolTipText
data.value: The desired quantizer to use. For lower bit-per-pixel formats it is recommended to enable dithering as well.

data.name: PredefinedColorsQuantizer.SystemDefault4BppPalette
data.value: System default 4 bpp palette (16 standard basic colors)

data.name: PredefinedColorsQuantizer.SystemDefault8BppPalette
data.value: System default 8 bpp palette (224 different colors and transparency)

data.name: PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Argb1555
data.value: ARGB1555 color space (32,768 different colors and transparency)

data.name: PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Argb8888
data.value: ARGB8888 color space (16.7M colors with 256 levels of transparency)

data.name: chbLinearColorSpace.ToolTipText
data.value:
When checked, quantizing (and dithering if selected) uses the linear color space rather than sRGB.
Affects blending with the background color if the target pixel format or the quantizer does not support transparency. Affects also how the result colors are determined for indexed (palette based) pixel formats, though this may be ignored if the quantizer uses direct mapping.
Please note though that if the result has transparency, the blending with the background is performed by the rendering engine. Use quantizers without alpha or set alpha threshold to zero to avoid mixing sRGB and linear blending.
Similarly, resizing the preview image is also performed by the rendering engine, which is not affected by this option. The apparent brightness of the result might be wrong when resized in the sRGB color space. Check the result in its actual size to avoid this issue.

data.name: btnBackColor.ToolTipText
data.value: When the selected pixel format or quantizer does not support gradient transparency, or dithering is selected, then specifies the background color. Alpha pixels that are considered opaque are blended with this color during the processing.

data.name: tbAlphaThreshold.ToolTipText
data.value: Specifies the alpha threshold under which the pixel is considered transparent. If 0, then the result will not have any transparent pixels. If 255, then all partially transparent pixels will turn transparent.

data.name: tbWhiteThreshold.ToolTipText
data.value: Determines the lowest input brightness between 0 and 255 to consider the result color white. Affects the brightness of the result, though an error diffusion ditherer may compensate the effect of this parameter.

data.name: tbNumColors.ToolTipText
data.value: Determines the maximum number of allowed colors the quantizer can use. The allowed maximum value depends on the pixel format of the result.

data.name: chbDirectMapping.ToolTipText
data.value:
Check to map any color directly to color palette index instead of searching for the nearest color, which is very fast but may end up in a result of a bit higher contrast than the original image. An error diffusion ditherer may compensate the effect of this parameter.
Uncheck to perform a lookup to determine nearest colors, which may be slower but more accurate.
When this option is enabled color lookup may ignore the working color space (though dithering still respects it if selected).

data.name: tbBitLevel.ToolTipText
data.value:
Determines the allowed number of bits used for each color channels. Higher value means more accuracy, larger target color space, slower processing and larger memory usage.
For example, if 1, then the result can have no more than 8 colors, or when 2, no more than 64 colors. For Octree and Wu quantizers it affects also the maximum number of possible monochromatic shades. For example, if 5 (which is the default for Wu quantizer with 256 colors), only 32 monochromatic shades can be differentiated.
⚠️ Caution: The Wu quantizer consumes at least 650 MB with the highest value, even for small images.

data.name: gbDitherer.ToolTipText
data.value: Check to use a ditherer. For high bit-per-pixel formats it makes little sense as for those its only practical effect is just removing possible partial transparency.

data.name: cmbDitherer.ToolTipText
data.value: The selected ditherer. Error diffusion ditherers do not support parallel processing but usually provide high quality. Others support parallel processing but the strength auto-calibration might not be optimal for a palette with unevenly distributed colors.

data.name: tbStrength.ToolTipText
data.value: The strength of the ditherer, or 0 to auto calibrate strength.

data.name: chbSerpentineProcessing.ToolTipText
data.value: When checked, the error propagation direction is altered from line to line. This helps to reduce the ripple effect of the error diffusion dithering.

data.name: chbByBrightness.ToolTipText
data.value:
Determines the way the error propagation is applied to the neighboring pixels.
In indetermined state (the default value) the method is detected from the pixel format or the selected quantizer. When unchecked, the quantization error is calculated for each color channels independently. When checked, the error propagation of the quantization error is performed by brightness based on human eye perception.

data.name: txtSeed.ToolTipText
data.value:
An integer seed to be used to produce a specific random dithering pattern. Leave it empty to use a random seed.
Using a specific seed disables parallel processing, which impacts performance on a multi-core CPU.

data.name: chbUseOSLanguage.ToolTipText
data.value: When checked, uses the language of the operating system. The possibly non-existing resources will be automatically generated.

data.name: chbAllowAnyLanguage.ToolTipText
data.value: Check to allow selecting languages with no existing localization. Can be used to generate new localizations for any language. Newly generated resources will contain English texts prefixed with "[T]". You can then edit the resources to translate these texts.

data.name: gbResxResourcesPath.ToolTipText
data.value: When checked, then you can specify an absolute path for the editable .resx resources.

data.name: chbHideDependencies.ToolTipText
data.value: When checked, hides the resources of the dependent libraries. It is allowed for a localization to contain the resources of the Imaging Tools application only.

data.name: txtFilter.ToolTipText
data.value: Filtering ignores case, accents and character width. Tip: use '[T]' to filter untranslated texts.
